metadata.description:
"◉◉◉" presents a collection of pointillistic drawings generated by p5js. However, the work deviates from the traditional method as employed by Georges Seurat; rather than placing the smallest units of dots, the process involves scaling down the dots from larger to smaller sizes. As a result, finer details are progressively drawn, creating a visual blend of colors as the dots overlap.
"◉◉◉" project is an exploration of pixels and dots in the computer, but also of painting itself.

The technique is an application of a simple random walk algorithm. Walkers, each designated with a color, traverse the canvas. The overlapping and colliding footprints of these walkers instigate a color-on-color confrontation, eventually creating distinguishable ground and figures. This process elicits the illusion of a visual object, exposing the viewer's cognitive processes and continuously reenacting the site of image formation.
In fact, I have painted such an abstract on a physical canvas before, and the way the p5js develops the sensation of brushstrokes and color combinations does not seem very different from the sensation of the paintbrush and canvas at that time.

Much like Damien Hirst's Spot Paintings, the multi-layered dots eventually settle at regular intervals after a specific number of iterations. The smallest dots, resembling the texture of a canvas, along with the added motion of the dots, akin to dripping paint, bestow the work with a more painterly flavor.
This piece serves as both a token of gratitude for my existing collectors and a technical demonstration of my craft.

2400 × 2400 px
p5js
2023 July
hasaqui

metadata.name: Heat Death #203
metadata.description:
Heat Death is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at The Ever-Evolving World of Art, Art Basel Hong-Kong, 2022

It aims to produce variation and detail from minimal logic.

The source code uses p5.js and consists of around 180 lines of code. It has been left unminified for the interested viewer to learn more.

metadata.name: MONOLITH #83
metadata.description:
Very limited facts are known about these strange monolithic structures. Black, rectilinear, similar to obsidian stone but made of strange materials. According to legend, an ancient civilization of high intelligence, called the Explorers of Latent Space, distributed hundreds of monoliths throughout time and space in order to study the behavior of species in the infinite Universe.

Some say that it is the divine intelligence of God. Others say that, in spite of their objectual and material condition, the monoliths possess their own consciousness and an intelligence beyond the natural and artificial. Their purpose or objective, to this day, remains a mystery.

_-_-_-_-_-_-_-_

this work is done only with code, using threejs and p5js
it might be a bit slow on low-end devices, be patient

metadata.name: Yashinoki #96
metadata.description:
Inspired by classic Japanese woodblock prints and cross-sections of palm tree (yashinoki) trunks. 

Controls in live mode:
- Press [s] to save a png


Made with code by AutoEclectus.
 AutoEclectus is an artist specialising in code-based generative works.

@autoeclectus everywhere:
- Links: https://autoeclectus.art
- Twitter: autoeclectus
- Instagram: autoeclectus

© AutoEclectus - NFT License Version 2.0 - September 2022

metadata.name: life is a (beautiful) mess #20
metadata.description:
when carefully applied, chaos brings things to life.

'life is a (beautiful) mess' was created as i led a certain amount of chaos take control of an animated textile algorithm i'm developing. 
as soon as it happened i realized that it was a great representation of our lives. 
each line represents one of us and the patterns that appear repeatedly are the situations we live which make us move, feel and be in a certain way. 
the image created is the sum of our paths in this life, as they only make sense when we look at them as one.

---

i hope you find it pleasant to watch this animation, how it develops and grows during aprox 1'30"
there are pieces drawn with the 4 typical school pen colors: black, green, blue and red. also a multicolor and a rare dark mode features.


press [s] to capture an image .png
press [r] to reload the animation
click the mouse to stop the animation
doubleclick the mouse to resume the animation

generative art created by mehno using p5js

metadata.name: Ir/rational Beauty #176
metadata.description:
Released on the occasion of the Tribute to Herbert W. Franke. www.tribute-hwf.com

"Since the classical age of Greece, the golden ratio has been well known as the most balanced and therefore most aesthetically perfect proportion. In fact, it is supposedly often found in the fine arts and architecture and it is certainly important in geometry. But where is the proof that it is really the most beautiful proportion?

"The computer is proving to be a useful tool in exact art theory. Works of computer art are produced with the help of programs that describe the logic of the construction and its relevant measures. By varying the parameters you can vary the shapes of objects, and on the basis of the reaction of the public you can determine the best option. So it is possible to find valid rules to design works of art.

"A statistical evaluation would be interesting. Please email me with your results for the optimal proportion."

I found it heartwarming that in 2011, Herbert W. Franke wrote the above, accompanied with a simple functional program on a Wolfram Demonstration page (https://demonstrations.wolfram.com/IsTheGoldenRatioReallyTheMostBeautifulProportion/) titled 'Is the Golden Ratio Really the Most Beautiful Proportion?' and invited people to submit their findings to him.

The main idea behind this project is ratios, a variety of them, used in a variety of ways, such as how a rectangle is repeatedly subdivided, or how it influences the aspect ratio of the piece, or how the colors in a palette are selected. These are represented in various styles, some of which are inspired by the aesthetic of Herbert W. Franke's diverse artworks, and his openness to experimentation with new technologies, such as plotter drawings, screens, screenprints, or 2D and 3D digital renderings.

This project, while not designed to be a formal statistical evaluation, is but my fun, colorful, and humble response to your inquiry, dear Herbert.

---

25% of primary sales will be donated on-chain to the Foundation Herbert W. Franke, with the goal of raising 20,000 Euros so that ZKM Karlsruhe can digitize Herbert W. Franke’s 1,800 manuscripts and make them publicly available. Any money raised beyond this goal will be donated to the Rütgers Foundation which supports children and young adults in Africa so that they can get access to and work with technology.

---

Controls:
• Double-click/tap or 'R' reassembles the piece (This automatically happens every minute)

Note: Some mints require WEBGL and/or may take several seconds to fully render.

Made in p5js
Created Oct 2022
Artist: @Yazid

metadata.name: Effluence #42
metadata.description:
“Through our eyes, the universe is perceiving itself. Through our ears, the universe is listening to its harmonies. We are the witnesses through which the universe becomes conscious of its glory, of its magnificence.”

-Alan Wilson Watts


---

Depending on the feature values, this artwork may take several seconds to render.
A modern, capable computer is advised.

To download image at different resolutions, press keys:

1. Low
2. Mid
3. High

---

10 first people minting at auction start price can request high-quality print at no additional cost (DM on Twitter for more details if interested)

Made with p5.js, curiosity and goodwill.

---

Daniel Aguilar
October 2022

Twitter: @protozoo
Instagram: @prtzart
Website: https://protozoo.xyz

metadata.name: Asterium #174
metadata.description:
Asterium is a token that will grow with you, for an entire year. Changing and morphing over time to eventually reach its equilibrium.

It is a token where I try to symbolize the journey of life.
Where looking back is the best way to look forward.
Where looking into the future is not a possibility.
Where each day is as uncertain as the next.

A token that will surprise you and have its ups and downs as it grows over time.



Pricing:
Dutch auction 64-16-8, where anybody that picks one up at 64 tez gets a print of how their galaxy looks on any day from the present to day 0. Meaning you can claim the print at any point in the future.

The print will be printed on high quality hahnemühle torchon paper at 30x40 cm (11.81 x 15.75 in). Printed at a local print shop here in Utrecht. This paper has a rough texture to it that matches the textures of space perfectly.



Usage:
- Hover over your Asterium to view the name, date, days passed, status and render stats.
- Double press to export the current frame as a .png image.
- Use the slider at the bottom to scroll back in time to the days before today, you can go as far back as day 0 and as far forwards as today.
- The token refreshes every hour, so framing it in a digital picture frame is totally possible!

metadata.name: fx(haish) / the Generator #349
metadata.description:
fx(haish) is my contribution to #fxhashturnsone
fx(haish) is not a finished product
fx(haish) is a co-creation experiment
fx(haish) is a fun exploration of a mixed GenAI process

fx(haish) is my Happy Birthday to fx(hash). 

Have fun, collectors!


// HOW TO PARTICIPATE

Step 1. Mint or collect “fx(haish) - the Generator”
Step 2. Visit https://www.arqtistic.com/fx(haish) to generate your “fx(haish) - The AI City” based on your mint. You have 20 tries.
Step 3. Await further instructions.


// FURTHER INFO

This algorithm has been designed to produce images which are suitable for the subsequent AI generation. The token consists of a random number of randomly placed and sized rectangles, filled with a noise gradient pattern. In short, Diffusion AI Models thrive on noise.

The AI generation uses Stable Diffusion 1.5 through an API designed by the 330ai team (@Pixelmindai). The WebUI has been developed by Nik0gda (@AntonCebanu2). AI Prompt has been designed (by me) to produce images of Cities, but you can possibly make it do other things, if you try hard enough.

metadata.name: YANF #94
metadata.description:
Yet Another Noises and Flows

After three works on landscapes I returned to an abstract work in which I used several kinds of noise fields and a different approach to flow lines.

In this work I use three intermediate images to generate the final image:
- on the first image to each pixels is assigned a color related to the value of the noise field in that point using the main color palette
- on the second image the gradient orientation (angle) of the field is used to assign colors using a secondary palette with the purpose of giving lights and shadows to the final image
- on the third image flow lines are drawn using the direction perpendicular to the gradient, in this way the flows are aligned to the contour lines

After the second and third step the new generated image is blended with the previous giving rise to the final image.

Developed with p5.js

Default resolution: 2400x1600, 1600x2400, 2000x2000 (3/2, 2/3, 1/1 aspect ratio)

[2] to redraw at double resolution (it takes four times then default)
[1] to redraw at default resolution
[s] to save a png at current resolution

Sources of variations are:
- 14 palettes
- 6 kinds of combinations of noise type and fractal type
- 8 kinds of cuts
- 3 kinds of aspect ratio
- 3 border thickness

This Generative Token uses the FastNoiseLite.js and chroma.js libraries.

Created by Andrea Belloni, fxhash: anbello, twitter: @Waterflowing0. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.

metadata.name: The Past Ahead #42
metadata.description:
Cyanotypes once were the most advanced technology to create images. When I see one today I look at it as a beautiful relic and I can't help but put my present in perspective. In these uncertain times the technologies we use to create are threatened with sudden extinction. But I feel joy in imagining our works joining the strata of history, a fallen species, the breeding ground of creations to come.

Controls :

• Press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to make a capture and download a PNG with a resolution of x1, x2, x3 or x4.

———————

The Past Ahead by Ferdinand Dervieux, 2022
Made with Unity
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Clerestory #24
metadata.description:
Windows welcome daylight, admit fresh air, and offer a view into the outside world. They rarely shatter, always confess the passage of time, and sometimes allow others a chance to look in.

What would the space you're in feel like if it had no windows?

'Clerestory' is an abstract exploration of stained glass windows, drafting shattered sketches for ten potential locations from various perspectives and moments in time. 

Made with WebGL, p5.js, and <3 | CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: System β #217
metadata.description:
α -> β is about "Increases in magnitude and decreases in computation". And still related the fleeting time in the generating process.

My role in this work is more of a discoverer than a creator. 

Try to reveal the possibilities of time perception in the generative art through negotiating with incomprehensible mathematical equations.

What I want to explore through this work is that behind the generated results, the dynamic process of generations are equally diverse and unpredictable.

When we watch the generating process displayed on the computer, changing instantly, moving, multiplying, disappearing, and we hesitate, wonder, pause, await, as if many possibilities of time perception have emerged in the fragmented moments.

_
press [1] -> β 
press [2] -> β⁰　 
press [3] -> β¹
-
Press [s] in live view to save as PNG.
Press [d] in live view to save as hi-res PNG.
-
If you need your collection in SVG format, feel free to DM me.

metadata.name: Vertical World #123
metadata.description:
This artwork is a kind of my inquiry about ambiguous boundaries.
I was a child who liked to draw but always been dissatisfied with my work. Now through coding, I was able to create the "feelings" that I wanted to express. This work is not to imitate a certain landscape or painting style, but simply paint with different brushes, and cooperate with the randomness of the computer.
"I" creates horizontal order, and "computer" creates vertical disorder. My intention is to create
ambiguous visuals in a way that doesn't give specific images, but vague atmosphere.
The meaning is computer-generated and positioned through your eyes.
(It may take more time to render if you using Firefox browser.)

- Press [s] to save png image

Created by haxenfan using p5js.

metadata.name: TEARS IN RAIN #225
metadata.description:
p5.js –> Blockchain


Controls:
[s] save as PNG.
[a] render using pixelDensity(5).
[x] render using pixelDensity(10).


Notes:
Rendered in WebGL.
Developed in Chrome, it might not work properly on other browsers.


Copyright (©) 2022 Thomas Noya
Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

◉_◉
tags: I've seen things you people wouldn't believe. Attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion. I watched C-beams glitter in the dark near the Tannhäuser Gate. All those moments will be lost in time. Like… tears in rain. Time to die.

metadata.name: Oxygen #116
metadata.description:
Oxygen makes strange forms of life thrive even in the darkest of places.

This is a generative piece using curated randomness to create textures, generate distortion fields, simulate growth and create compositions.

The work is best viewed in high resolution, but due to the time it takes to render, the preview image is capped to only 1000 pixels in height. You can change the resolution by pressing keys

- 'm' for medium  (height=2000px)
- 'l' for large (height=3500px)
- 'x' for extra large (height=5000px) 

outputs. 

Press 's' to save the output as a PNG file.

For even larger outputs, you can open the work in live mode and append the text '?size=10000' to the URL. Here, you can change the number (10000) to the desired height in pixels. 

Please note, that a very high-resolution image may take a very long time to render and some browsers are not able to save the image. However, even a 10000 pixels tall outputs have been generated during testing.

metadata.name: Corium #281
metadata.description:
The Corium is a roughly spherical mass (diameter ~1km), of currently unknown origins situated within the core region of the solar system's asteroid belt.
The body was discovered during a uranium extraction mission undertaken by ET Resources at the behest of Station 733-H (Mars colony) leadership, when ionising radiation levels detected by deployed surface craft exceeded equipment and personnel tolerance levels by many orders of magnitude.

While ETR crew were quick to respond to local abort orders (27 minutes from initial readings to fleet reorientation); Station 733-H made the determination that radiation exposure levels were already far in excess of anything that could be reasonably mitigated upon the ETR fleet's return.
The ETR fleet was ordered to jettison fuel reserves under Section 9 of the Space Corporations Act (Mars) approximately 90 minutes after the readings were initially reported. It is understood that all deployed personnel accessed their barbiturate rations within the following 24 hours.

The fleet itself remains in position some ~3000kms from The Corium, with plans to relocate the vessels still underway (albeit a low priority).


STATION 733-H OBSERVATION REPORT SUMMARY (14.1.1)

To date, remote analysis suggests that the body is compositionally similar to corium deposits observed following terrestrial nuclear disasters, consisting of a range of solidified radioactive compounds as well as a number of currently unidentified metal alloys. More in-depth analysis has been impossible to date due to the rapid physical decay of personnel and equipment as their proximity to samples reach a critical threshold.

All samples have so far been extruded from the surface of The Corium via laser, and maneuvered into orbit around Mars at the edge of it's sphere of influence (at a distance of no less than 50,000kms from Station 733-H), via projectile barrage and gas envelopment.

The surface of The Corium itself is littered with an array of clearly engineered forms; radial and rectangular patterns, deep crevasses, mazes and grids with only a select few areas resembling the pools of lava observed where Corium has formed terrestrially (it is unclear whether these deposits have formed since the surface was initially engineered).

The accompanying files are LIDAR renders of the extracted samples in proximity to Station 733-H and are marked for dissemination to terrestrial research teams on Mars. Study of The Corium remains the sole priority of Station 733-H research personnel, as any risks presented to the solar system or its inhabitants are currently not well understood.

--------------------------------------

The piece will render from the top right and might take ~5-10 seconds to begin.

Append "&print=true" to the live render URL for a hi-res output.
